hints.content: Start by defining the `ArrayWrapper` class. In the constructor, make sure to initialize an instance variable that will hold the array of integers passed to it.

Remember that you need to implement the addition operation between two instances of `ArrayWrapper`. In JavaScript, you can do this by defining the `valueOf` method, which allows you to specify how an object should be converted to a primitive value.
When implementing the addition, think about how you can access the array stored in each instance of `ArrayWrapper`. You will need to sum the elements of both arrays.
Consider edge cases where one or both arrays could be empty. What should the sum be in those cases? Make sure to handle these scenarios gracefully.
To convert the instance to a string, you can define the `toString` method. This method should return a string formatted as a comma-separated list of the array elements enclosed in brackets.
When implementing the `toString` method, remember to check if the array is empty. An empty array should return '[]' rather than just an empty string.
For the addition operation, you can use the `reduce` method to sum the elements of the arrays. This can help simplify your code and make it more readable.
Make sure to test your class with various inputs, including arrays with different lengths and values. This will help ensure your implementation is robust.
Consider how you will handle the case when both arrays are empty. The expected output for this case should be 0.

Your final implementation should allow for instances of `ArrayWrapper` to be added together using the `+` operator, which will invoke the `valueOf` method. Ensure this method returns the correct sum of all elements.

questionNotes: The constructor accepts an array of integers.
The addition operation should return the sum of all elements in both arrays.
The `String()` function should return a comma-separated string in brackets.
Handle cases where arrays may be empty.
